temperatureScale.title: Updated Body Temperature Scale: Old vs New Standards

q1.question: Is 36.4Â°C (97.5Â°F) too low? Why am I below 98.6Â°F?
q1.answer: 36.4Â°C is NOT too low. Stanford Medicine's 2020 research shows average body temperatures have dropped 0.03Â°C per decade since the 1860s. The 37Â°C (98.6Â°F) 'standard' is outdated. Modern normal range is 36.4Â°C to 36.6Â°C (97.5Â°F to 97.9Â°F). Your temperature is perfectly healthy.

q2.question: Why have body temperatures dropped since the 1800s?
q2.answer: Stanford researchers identified three factors: 1) Better health and lower inflammation due to medical advances; 2) Reduced metabolic rate from modern sedentary lifestyles; 3) Climate-controlled environments reducing body workload. 36.4Â°C reflects these improvements, not a problem.

q3.question: What did the Stanford body temperature study find?
q3.answer: The 2020 Stanford study analyzed 677,423 temperature measurements from 1892-2017. Key findings: Men's temps dropped 0.59Â°C, women's 0.32Â°C. Average temps decreased 0.03Â°C per birth decade. The 37Â°C (98.6Â°F) standard from 1868 is no longer accurate for modern populations. 36.4Â°C-36.6Â°C is the new normal.

q4.question: Is 36.4Â°C normal for babies and children?
q4.answer: Yes. Children show the same temperature decline as adults in Stanford's research. 36.4Â°C (97.5Â°F) is a healthy temperature for all ages. Pediatricians now recognize broader normal ranges. Contact doctors only for consistent readings below 35.5Â°C or accompanying illness symptoms.

q5.question: Should I trust modern 36.4Â°C standards or old 37Â°C?
q5.answer: Trust modern research. The 37Â°C (98.6Â°F) standard comes from a single 1868 German study of 25,000 people. Modern Stanford research (2020) uses 677,000+ measurements. Medical institutions including Cleveland Clinic and Johns Hopkins now accept 36.4Â°C-36.6Â°C as the updated normal range. 36.4Â°C is medically sound.

q6.question: How do I convert 36.4Â°C to Fahrenheit correctly?
q6.answer: To convert 36.4Â°C to Fahrenheit: Multiply 36.4 by 9/5 (or 1.8) = 65.52; Add 32 to the result: 65.52 + 32 = 97.52; Rounded: 36.4Â°C = 97.5Â°F. This temperature represents the modern average lower limit according to 2020 Stanford Medical research.
